title: Can two parents raise their child to be a person they like if both parents have widely opposing views on nearly everything? - Quora

response.answer_text: While my brothers and I were raised with morals and values. We each took a different road once we moved out on our own. I got my PhD. and retired as the head of the foreign language department of a foreign university. 2 divorces (My bipolar had a lot to do with that) My youngest brother had 3 boys, married his high school sweetheart. One of his boys just graduated from West Point. My middle brother took a little longer to graduate from college but now heads a successful health care management company based here in Houston. Happily married with one boy. All that to say as parents just be the type of person you want your child to be.

All four of my children are good kids. They are very respectful and polite. However my husband and i have different views on things the boys (my 2 youngest) need to be doing around the house. I say they need to help out and clean up after themself where as my husband says they will just make a bigger mess and I should just do it myself so I dont get stressed out and have to yell at them. My husband and I don't agree on much when it comes to the boys and chores.

Yes if they respect each other. Certainly. If their conversations are civil, genuine and respectful the child could learn a great deal and they could both like him as a person (all other things being equal). On the other hand you could get parents who NEVER have opposing views who could do a terrible job by never discussing anything. Its way more about respect than opposing or similar views.

Yes, if you respect each other and others with differing views your children will likely imitate that and grow up to be nice people. As for individual ideas, they will randomly accept or rebel against them - or maybe just ignore them, whether both parents agree or not. They aren’t going to be clones of either of you.

Do these parents like each other? If not: why are they parents? Tongue-in-cheek aside: of course they can. They just need to love their kid and express their love in a healthy (non-possessive, mature boundaries, accepting/non-judgmental, wholehearted, …) way. And hopefully not be gazing at their narcissistic navels, considering their kid just an extension of their, in that case, very immature self.

A child will become what they become. Following any certain parenting style does not guarantee that you will like your child in the end. You can, however, love your child no matter who they become, even if you don't like them. That is your choice, and the only part you have any control over. The rest is luck.
I’ll let you know when my kids grow up. My wife is an artist - RISD grad. I’m in IT. The kids are coming along fine now. Excelsior!
That would depend on the child’s personality. But if parents can’t agree on how to raise their child, then how do you expect the child to be the way you both want him/her to be?
I believe it is most important for the child to become a person who likes himself or herself. The child will decide which of the parents’ views to accept or reject.
